name: Trust Building/Durham Visitor Info Center
description: The historic Trust Building, a Beaux Arts-style structure, was the tallest office building in the state at the time of its construction in 1905. It featured Durham's first elevator and housed a mix of businesses including Fidelity Bank run by Benjamin Duke. It is still a multi-tenant office building including the Durham Convention & Visitors Bureau where visitors can get directions, maps, and travel tips.

name: Main Street
description: A series of architecturally and historically significant properties, many with lofts/residences along the second story.

name: Old Hill Building
description: 1925 Georgian revival Old Hill Building commissioned by John Sprunt Hill.

name: Temple Building
description: 1909 Spanish colonial-style Temple Building built with leftover materials from the 1909 Watts Hospital.

name: Former Kronheimer's Department Store
description: Benjamin Franklin Kronheimer constructed the building between 1898 and 1902 as Kronheimer's department store, which he operated throughout the early part of the 20th century. It continued to house retail establishments through the mid 20th century including Raylass and Revco.

name: Snow Building
description: One of Durham’s finest art deco structures, built in 1933. Its elevator was the last in the state run by a full-time operator.

name: Five Points/Muirhead Plaza
description: Includes site of 1906 invention of BC Headache Powder.
location: Intersection of W Main, E Chapel Hill, and Morris St

name: Civil Rights mural
description: The Durham Civil Rights mural brings to life some lesser-known stories of the local civil rights movement in vivid colors. Artist Brenda Miller Holmes and Dr. Benjamin Speller, former Dean of Library Sciences at North Carolina Central University, developed the concept for the mural, with input from 30 community members. The mural was completed in 2015. More detailed information can be found at http://www.muraldurham.com/.
location: At the parking lot next to 120 Morris St.

name: Durham Arts Council
description: Former 1906 Central High School and later City Hall. Now 52,000-sq.- ft. arts center with performance space, three galleries, and meeting rooms.

name: Museum of Durham History Hub
description: The Durham History Hub serves as a physical outpost of the Museum of Durham History website. The Museum uses stories about people, places and things to foster curiosity, encourage further inquiry, and promote an understanding of diverse perspectives about the Durham community and its history. The exhibits are rotated on a frequent basis, so there is always something new to see!

name: Durham Centre Building & Plaza
description: Fifteen-story commercial building housing the Greater Durham Chamber of Commerce and Duke Clinical Research Institute, a powerhouse behind research trials as well as a major area employer.

name: Carolina Theatre
description: Renovated 1926 Beaux Arts-style theater housing the historic Fletcher Hall for live performances, as well as two cinemas for year round film screenings. Originally named Durham Auditorium, by the 1940s and 50s the Carolina Theatre was a hub for arts with lives shows featuring stars like Ronald Reagan and Katherine Hepburn. In the early 1960s the segregated theater was the center of civil rights protests. Later decades saw the theater fall into decline, being considerd for demolition until a volunteer effort successfully saved and preserved the theater.

name: Civic Center Plaza
description: Includes fountains, outdoor gathering space, and seating.

name: Durham Armory
description: Durham’s original Civic Center from the late 1950s to 1989. Built by the Works Progress Administration in 1937 to house a National Guard machine-gun company.

name: The Durham Convention Center
description: Anchors the Durham Convention Center Complex and includes 102,940-netsq.-ft. of exhibition/banquet halls, theaters, meeting rooms, reception areas, galleries, and an outdoor plaza. Durham can host most of the nation’s conventions and meetings.

name: CCB Plaza
description: Named for the former Central Carolina Bank, the plaza’s focus is The Major, a lifesized, one-ton bronze bull a legacy emblem of Durham), commissioned by the bank and crafted by local artisans at the George Watts Hill Pavilion for the Arts. The plaza is a central gathering place in downtown where many community based events and performances take place.
location: E Chapel Hill and Corcoran St

name: Bull City Business Center
description: Former home of The HeraldSun newspaper; built in the late 1920s with Italian Renaissance styling. Now home to Downtown Durham, Inc.

name: The Durham Hotel
description: Now a boutique hotel, this mid-century building is a former Home Savings Bank
location: 315 East Chapel Hill Street, Durham, NC, United States

name: Through This Lens
description: Gallery of fine art photography that also offers books, posters, and other items related to photography.

name: Durham Arts Place
description: Art studio complex.

name: Unscripted Hotel
description: Unscripted Hotel opened its doors in the summer of 2017, after an extensive facelift of the old Jack Tar Motor Lodge, which was originally built in the early 1960’s. Alongside, minimalist-styled rooms, visitors have options to choose when they’re ready to relax with a beverage. The Patio is a poolside lounge and The Studio, offers a mid-century styled rec-room atmosphere.

name: City Center
description: A 27-story skyscraper, which will be home to condos, retail, and office space, is under construction at the site of the former Downtown Durham Woolworth store. In the late 1950s, Rev. Douglas Moore and Floyd McKissick of Durham pioneered the student sit-in movement in several states and trained participants at churches around the community. After national media reported a 1960 sit-in held in nearby Greensboro, Durham protesters began a sit-in at the Woolworth lunch counter – the first attended by Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

name: Historic Parrish Street/ Black Wall Street
description: Known as America’s Black Wall Street from the 1900s. In the 1960s, the street again attracted national attention as a place where civil rights pioneers staged sit-ins and received a memorable visit from Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Features six public art sculptures marking the significance of Historic Parrish Street.

name: 116 West Parrish - National Historic Monument
description: Built in 1921 for North Carolina Mutual Life Insurance Co.; later home to and still a branch of Mechanics and Farmers Bank, one of the oldest African American-owned banks in the country.

name: Parrish Street Forum
description: The Parrish Street Common Room is an interpretive space honoring the legacy of African-American entrepreneurs and businesses that developed America’s Black Wall Street. Located in the original 1908 headquarters of Mechanic and Farmers Bank.

name: Orange Street Mall
description: Brick walkway named for a 19thcentury tobacco brand Orange of Durham.
location: E Chapel Hill St and W Parrish St

name: US Postal Service - Downtown
description: 1934 neoclassical building paid for in 15 minutes of its first day of operation by taxes on local tobacco.
location: 323 E Chapel Hill St, Durham, NC 27701, USA

name: Rogers Alley
description: Three buildings converted into residential, restaurants, etc., including the 1904 fire station and Wright Building, long known as Roger’s Pharmacy.
location: Corner of Mangum St & E Parrish St

name: Durham City Hall & City Hall Plaza
description: Recognized as a place by the Post Office between 1819 and 1823, Durham gained its current name in 1853, and was incorporated by the state in 1869.

name: Trinity United Methodist Church
description: T1924 Gothic revival church noted for wood carvings.

name: Former Durham County Department of Social Services
description: Established in 1919. The new social services building is at E5.

name: Historic Durham County Courthouse
description: Renovated 1916 neoclassical revival that replaced the 1887 courthouse that once stood on this site.

name: Former Durham County Judicial Building
description: Site was once the famous Rialto Theater, poolroom, barbershop, and jazz bar.

name: Celebrate mural
description: Celebrate mural created by Michael Brown in 1996.

name: Kress Building
description: Built in 1932, one of the largest and most elaborately detailed art deco buildings in North Carolina and the first building in Durham to have air conditioning. Now luxury condos and offices of Greenfire Development.

name: Historic Baldwin Building
description: 1927 neoclassical building; now home to loft-style apartments and a restaurant.

name: 1893 Queen Anne-style building
description: The oldest building that remains inside the Downtown Loop.

name: “City View” - First National Bank Building
description: Originally the site of the 1840s home of Durham namesake Dr. Bartlett Durham. Present building is the neoclassical 1914 First National Bank, with notable cast-iron, flower-swagged canopy.

name: 21c Museum Hotel
description: This boutique hotel is home to a museum that is free and open to the public. It’s located in the historic 1935 art deco Hill Building, designed by the same architectural firm that designed the Empire State Building.
